patterns: How can I contact the UCSC Financial Aid Office?
What is the contact information for the Financial Aid Office?
How do I reach the Financial Aid Office?
responses:
You can contact the UCSC Financial Aid Office by our zoom drop in, phone at (831) 459-2963, or by email at finaid@ucsc.edu.
 You can find our detailed contact information at https://financialaid.ucsc.edu/about-us/contact_information.html

patterns: What are the office hours of the UCSC Financial Aid Office?
When is the Financial Aid Office open?
What are the working hours of the Financial Aid Office?
what are your service hours?
responses: We can be contacted through zoom, phones, emails and in-person. Our zoom hours are 10 AM - 1 PM (Monday to Friday). Our phone lines are open from 10 AM - 4 PM (Monday to Friday). Our front counter is open from 1 PM - 4 PM (Monday to Friday). You can find more about our service hours by visiting out Contact Information page!

patterns: front counter
office address
counter hours
where are you located?
Where is the financial aid office?
responses: Our front counter is located at 205 Hahn Student Services, 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz, CA 95064. The front counter hours are 1PM-4PM Monday-Friday.

patterns: What is the mailing address of the UCSC Financial Aid Office?
Where should I send documents to the Financial Aid Office?
What is the postal address of the Financial Aid Office?
What is your mailing address?
do you have a mailing address?
how can I mail documents to the office?
responses: You can send documents to the UCSC Financial Aid Office at the following address: UC Santa Cruz, Financial Aid and Scholarships Office, 205 Hahn Student Services, 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz, CA 95064.
The mailing address for the Financial Aid Office is UC Santa Cruz, Financial Aid and Scholarships Office, 205 Hahn Student Services, 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz, CA 95064.
Documents can be mailed to the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office, UC Santa Cruz, 205 Hahn Student Services, 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz, CA 95064.

patterns: What services does the UCSC Financial Aid Office provide?
What assistance can I get from the Financial Aid Office?
What issues does the Financial Aid Office handle?
responses: The UCSC Financial Aid Office provides assistance with financial aid applications, award disbursement, scholarships, and financial literacy resources. We can help with questions related to grants, loans, work-study, and other financial aid programs.

patterns: Part-time enrollment
Part time enrollment
Minimum enrollment
Official Part-Time Program
how many credits do I need for financial aid?
how many units are required for aid at UCSC?
how many units do I need for financial aid?
What is the part time enrollment policy at UCSC?
responses:
UC Santa Cruz is a full-time enrollment institution, but there are circumstances where students may need to go part-time. To be approved for the Official Part-Time Program and avoid billing of partial aid, students must contact the Office of the Registrar.
Approved part-time students should enroll in 6-10 credits and may receive a 50 percent reduction in tuition fee and nonresident supplemental tuition, if applicable. Please reach out to the Office of the Registrar for eligibility requirements and more information.
If a student does not enroll in the Official Part-Time Program and is enrolled in less than 12 credits on the add/drop/swap date of the quarter, they will be billed for full-time tuition and fees. In such cases, financial aid will be adjusted based on the number of credits enrolled, as per federal, state, and university grant requirements.
Grant funds will be adjusted as follows:
- 9-11 credits: 75% of the original grant amount
- 6-8 credits: 50% of the original grant amount
- 5 or less credits: 25% of the original Pell Grant and 0% for all other aid.
Please note that Cal Grant recipients must fulfill specific credit requirements as per AB 2248 to maintain eligibility for the Cal Grant program.

patterns: What is the FAFSA?
Can you provide an overview of the FAFSA?
What does FAFSA stand for?
responses: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is a form that students must complete to apply for federal financial aid for college or career school. It collects information about the student's family income, assets, and other factors to determine their eligibility for grants, scholarships, work-study, and federal student loans.

patterns: Who is eligible to submit the FAFSA?
Am I eligible to apply for the FAFSA?
What are the eligibility requirements for the FAFSA?
what is the eligibility criteria for filing the fafsa?
responses: To be eligible to submit the FAFSA, you must be a U.S. citizen, a U.S. national, or an eligible non-citizen. You must also have a high school diploma or equivalent, be enrolled or accepted in an eligible degree or certificate program, and have a valid Social Security Number.

patterns: How do I apply for the FAFSA?
What is the process to complete the FAFSA?
Can you explain how to fill out the FAFSA form?
responses: To apply for the FAFSA, you can complete the form online at the official website, fafsa.ed.gov. You'll need to gather your personal and financial information, including tax returns, W-2 forms, and other relevant documents. The FAFSA form will guide you through a series of questions to determine your eligibility for financial aid.

patterns: What is the deadline for submitting the FAFSA?
When should I submit the FAFSA form?
When is the FAFSA due?
responses: March 2nd is the priority deadline for undergraduate students to submit a FAFSA application. This deadline is important to be considered for all types of aid administered by UC Santa Cruz.

patterns: What do I need for filing the FAFSA?
What documents do I need to complete the FAFSA?
Can you provide a list of required documents for the FAFSA?
What information and paperwork should I have when filling out the FAFSA?
What is needed to complete the fafsa?
responses: When completing the FAFSA, you'll need your Social Security Number, driver's license (if applicable), federal income tax returns, W-2 forms, records of untaxed income, bank statements, and information about your assets. If you're a dependent student, you'll also need your parents' financial information.

patterns: Am I considered a dependent or independent student for the FAFSA?
How do I determine if I'm a dependent or independent student on the FAFSA?
What factors determine my dependency status on the FAFSA?
Dependency status for the FAFSA
How can I be considered independent for the fafsa?
responses:
The FAFSA uses specific criteria to determine whether you're considered a dependent or independent student. Factors such as your age, marital status, enrollment in graduate school, military service, and legal dependents affect your dependency status. The FAFSA form will guide you through the questions to determine your appropriate status.
Please consult https://studentaid.gov/apply-for-aid/fafsa/filling-out/dependency when determining your dependency status.

patterns: Do I need to renew the FAFSA each year?
How often do I need to submit the FAFSA?
What is the process for renewing the FAFSA?
responses: Yes, you must renew the FAFSA each year to continue receiving federal student aid. The renewal process allows you to update your financial and personal information for the upcoming academic year. You can use the FAFSA Renewal Application, which pre-fills some information from the previous year's FAFSA to streamline the process.

patterns: What is a FAFSA PIN?
Do I need a PIN to complete the FAFSA?
How do I obtain a FAFSA PIN?
responses: A FAFSA PIN is a personal identification number used to electronically sign the FAFSA form. However, the FAFSA PIN has been replaced with the FSA ID, which provides access to various federal student aid websites. You can create an FSA ID at fsaid.ed.gov.

patterns: What is FAFSA verification?
Why am I selected for FAFSA verification?
What should I do if my FAFSA is selected for verification?
responses: FAFSA verification is a process where the financial information reported on the FAFSA is verified for accuracy. Some FAFSA applications are randomly selected for verification, while others are chosen based on specific criteria. If your FAFSA is selected for verification, you'll need to provide additional documentation to confirm the accuracy of the information provided.

patterns: What is the difference between dependent and independent students on the FAFSA?
How does dependency status affect financial aid on the FAFSA?
Can you explain the impact of being a dependent or independent student on the FAFSA?
How can I be considered independent for fafsa?
responses:
The dependency status on the FAFSA determines whether you're required to provide your parents' financial information. Dependent students include most traditional undergraduate students who are typically supported by their parents financially. Independent students have additional eligibility for certain types of aid if they meet specific criteria, such as being at least 24 years old, married, a graduate student, or having legal dependents.
A list of all of the criteria can be found at https://studentaid.gov/apply-for-aid/fafsa/filling-out/dependency

patterns: What is the California Dream Act Application?
Can you explain CADAA?
Tell me about the CADAA.
Can you tell me about the california dream application?
responses: The California Dream Act Application (CADAA) is an application that allows eligible undocumented students to apply for state financial aid in California. It provides access to various state financial aid programs, such as Cal Grants, Chafee Grants, Middle Class Scholarships, UC Grants, CSU Grants, community college fee waivers, and some institutional aid programs.

patterns: Who is eligible for CADAA?
Who can apply for CADAA?
What are the eligibility requirements for CADAA?
responses: Undocumented students who meet specific criteria are eligible for CADAA. These criteria include attending an eligible California high school, graduating from a California high school or equivalent, and meeting AB 540 or AB 2000 eligibility requirements. Students must not hold a valid nonimmigrant visa.

patterns: How do I apply for CADAA?
What is the application process for CADAA?
Where can I submit my CADAA application?
responses: To apply for CADAA, you can complete the application online at the official California Student Aid Commission (CSAC) website. Make sure to gather all the required documents, including the CADAA application form, the California Dream Act Affidavit, income and tax information, and other supporting documents as requested by the California Student Aid Commission.

patterns: What documents do I need for CADAA?
Can you provide a list of required documents for CADAA?
What paperwork should I have when applying for CADAA?
responses: When applying for CADAA, you may need to provide documents such as the CADAA application form, the California Dream Act Affidavit, income and tax information, and any other supporting documents required by the specific state aid programs you're applying for. It's important to review the documentation requirements provided by the California Student Aid Commission.

patterns: What types of financial aid can I receive through CADAA?
What grants or scholarships are available through CADAA?
Can I get state financial aid with CADAA?
responses: CADAA provides eligible students access to various types of state financial aid programs, including Cal Grants, Chafee Grants, Middle Class Scholarships, UC Grants, CSU Grants, community college fee waivers, and some institutional aid programs. The specific types and amounts of aid you may receive depend on your eligibility and the policies of the colleges or universities you apply to.

patterns: What is the deadline for CADAA?
When is the CADAA application deadline?
By when should I submit my CADAA application?
when is the dream application due?
responses: March 2nd is the priority deadline for undergraduate students to submit the CADAA. This deadline is important to be considered for all types of aid administered by UC Santa Cruz.

patterns: Can I apply for CADAA if I have Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) status?
Are DACA students eligible for CADAA?
Can undocumented students with DACA apply for CADAA?
responses: Yes, students with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) status are eligible to apply for CADAA. DACA students should follow the same CADAA application process and meet the eligibility requirements set by the California Student Aid Commission.

patterns: Can I apply for CADAA if I am not a California resident?
Are out-of-state students eligible for CADAA?
Can non-residents apply for CADAA?
responses: To be eligible for CADAA, you must meet the residency requirements outlined by the California Dream Act. This includes attending an eligible California high school, graduating from a California high school or equivalent, and meeting the AB 540 or AB 2000 eligibility requirements. Non-residents may not be eligible for CADAA.

patterns: Can I apply for CADAA if I am currently enrolled in a college or university?
Is CADAA available for current college students?
Can I apply for CADAA after starting college?
responses: Yes, you can apply for CADAA even if you are currently enrolled in college. The CADAA application is available to both prospective and current college students who meet the eligibility requirements. It's important to review the specific deadlines and requirements provided by the California Student Aid Commission or your college's financial aid office.

patterns: Do I need to have a Social Security Number (SSN) to apply for CADAA?
Can I apply for CADAA if I don't have n SSN?
Is a SSN required for CADAA?
responses: No, having a Social Security Number (SSN) is not required to apply for CADAA. Undocumented students can submit the CADAA application regardless of their SSN status. It's important to follow the application guidelines and provide the necessary documentation as requested by the California Student Aid Commission.

patterns: What is the eligibility criteria for Cal Grants?
How do I qualify for a Cal Grant?
What are the requirements for Cal Grants?
responses: The eligibility criteria for Cal Grants vary depending on the specific Cal Grant program. Generally, eligibility is based on factors such as financial need, academic achievement, graduation from a California high school or equivalent, and meeting the GPA requirements outlined by CSAC. To determine your eligibility, you must submit your high school GPA by the specified deadline.

patterns: How do I apply for a Cal Grant?
What is the application process for Cal Grants?
Where can I submit my Cal Grant application?
responses: To apply for a Cal Grant, you must complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) or the California Dream Act Application (CADAA). Additionally, you must submit your verified high school GPA by the March 2 deadline. The application can be submitted online through the official CSAC website or by mail. Be sure to review the specific requirements provided by CSAC.

patterns: What types of Cal Grants are available?
Can you explain the different types of Cal Grants?
Tell me about Cal Grant A, B, and C.
responses: There are three types of Cal Grants: Cal Grant A, Cal Grant B, and Cal Grant C. Cal Grant A is for students pursuing a four-year degree program, Cal Grant B is for students from disadvantaged backgrounds, and Cal Grant C is for students pursuing a vocational or technical program. Each type has specific eligibility requirements, including meeting the GPA requirements, as determined by CSAC.

patterns: What are the award amounts for Cal Grants?
How much money can I receive from a Cal Grant?
Can you tell me about the Cal Grant award?
responses: The award amounts for Cal Grants vary depending on the type of Cal Grant and your financial need. Cal Grant A awards can cover tuition and fees at public and private colleges, while Cal Grant B awards may include an additional access award for living expenses. Cal Grant C awards assist with tuition and training costs at vocational schools. The specific award amounts are determined by CSAC based on available funding and program criteria. It's important to note that Cal Grant eligibility and award amounts are also influenced by your GPA.

patterns: What is the renewal process for Cal Grants?
How do I renew my Cal Grant?
Do I need to reapply for Cal Grants every year?
responses: To renew your Cal Grant, you must meet certain requirements, including maintaining satisfactory academic progress, enrolling in an eligible program, and completing the necessary financial aid forms each year. In addition, you must meet the GPA requirements as outlined by CSAC. Renewal processes may vary depending on the specific Cal Grant program. It's important to stay informed about the renewal requirements and deadlines provided by CSAC.

patterns: How to send my GPA?
Submitting GPA for Cal Grant
GPA submission process
Automatic GPA submission for continuing students
Does UCSC automatically submit GPA for Cal Grant?
GPA submission process for continuing students
responses:
To send your GPA for Cal Grant consideration, please follow these guidelines:
1. Contact your school's registrar or counseling office to request an official copy of your GPA.
2. Ensure that the GPA is provided on official school letterhead or through an official electronic transcript.
3. Submit the official GPA document to the Cal Grant processing agency or the California Student Aid Commission (CSAC) as instructed.

For detailed instructions and any specific requirements, it is recommended to visit the [Cal Grant GPA Submission](https://www.csac.ca.gov/post/cal-grant-gpa-verification-form) page on our website.
For continuing students at UCSC, the GPA submission for Cal Grant is handled automatically by the university. UCSC electronically submits the required GPA information to the California Student Aid Commission (CSAC) on behalf of eligible students. It is important to ensure that your academic records are up to date and that you meet the eligibility criteria for automatic GPA submission. For further details or any specific questions, it is recommended to contact the UCSC Financial Aid Office.

patterns: How is financial aid disbursed at UCSC?
When do I receive my financial aid disbursement?
Tell me about financial aid disbursement at UC Santa Cruz.
responses: Financial aid disbursement at UC Santa Cruz typically occurs at the beginning of each quarter/semester. The funds are directly applied to your student account to cover tuition, fees, and other university charges. Any remaining funds after paying your university charges are disbursed to you through your chosen refund preference, such as direct deposit or a paper check. You can view the specific disbursement dates and details on the UCSC Financial Aid website: [UCSC Financial Aid Disbursement](https://financialaid.ucsc.edu/next-steps/disbursement-of-aid.html).

patterns: How can I set up my refund preference for financial aid disbursement?
What are my options for receiving financial aid refunds?
Can you explain the refund process for financial aid at UCSC?
responses: To set up your refund preference for financial aid disbursement, you need to log in to your student portal and navigate to the My Account section. There, you can select your preferred method of receiving refunds, such as direct deposit or a paper check. Detailed instructions and options are available on the UCSC Financial Aid website: [UCSC Financial Aid Disbursement](https://financialaid.ucsc.edu/next-steps/disbursement-of-aid.html).

patterns: What should I do if I haven't received my financial aid disbursement?
My financial aid hasn't been disbursed
I am waiting for financial aid to disburse
my financial aid disbursement is pending
responses: If you haven't received your financial aid disbursement by the scheduled disbursement date, you should first check your student portal for any outstanding requirements or notifications. It's also a good idea to review your financial aid award status and ensure that you have completed all necessary steps for disbursement. If you have further concerns, you can contact the UCSC Financial Aid Office directly for assistance. Their contact information can be found on the UCSC Financial Aid website: [UCSC Financial Aid Contact](https://financialaid.ucsc.edu/about-us/contact_information.html).

patterns: Can I use my financial aid refund for expenses other than tuition and fees?
What can I use my financial aid disbursement for?
Are there any restrictions on how I can spend my financial aid refund?
responses: Financial aid refunds at UCSC are intended to assist with education-related expenses, including tuition, fees, books, and other educational costs. However, once the funds are disbursed to you, you have the flexibility to use them for various expenses related to your education. It's important to manage your funds wisely and prioritize your educational needs. If you have specific questions about allowable expenses, you can refer to the UCSC Financial Aid Office or the UCSC Financial Aid website for guidance.

patterns: What happens if my financial aid disbursement exceeds my university charges?
Will I receive a refund if my financial aid exceeds my tuition?
Can I use the excess financial aid for other expenses?
responses: If your financial aid disbursement exceeds your university charges (such as tuition, fees, and other expenses), you may be eligible for a refund of the excess funds. The refund can be used to cover other education-related expenses, such as textbooks, housing, transportation, and personal costs. You can manage your refund preference and ensure a timely refund by following the instructions provided by UCSC on the Financial Aid Disbursement page: [UCSC Financial Aid Disbursement](https://financialaid.ucsc.edu/next-steps/disbursement-of-aid.html).

patterns: How many units do I need to be eligible for financial aid during UCSC Summer Session?
What is the minimum unit requirement for summer financial aid at UCSC?
ow many credits do I need for summer financial aid?
How does financial aid work for the summer session?
how many units do I need for summer financial aid?
responses: To be eligible for financial aid during UCSC Summer Session, you generally need to enroll in a minimum of 6 units. This limit applies cummalatively to Session I and Session II. Enrolling in less than 6 units may affect your financial aid eligibility. However, it's always best to check with the UCSC Financial Aid Office for specific information regarding your situation.

patterns: Does financial aid for UCSC Summer Session cover housing?
Can I use financial aid to pay for housing during UCSC Summer Session?
Are there specific funds available for housing through financial aid during summer at UCSC?
responses: Generally, financial aid for UCSC Summer Session does not cover housing expenses. However, if you receive an excess amount of aid after tuition and other university charges have been paid, you can use those funds to help with housing expenses. It's important to manage your finances wisely and use any excess aid for education-related expenses, including housing, if needed.

patterns: Tell me more about UCSC's Summer Edge program.
What is the purpose of the Summer Edge program at UCSC?
How can I benefit from UCSC's Summer Edge program?
responses: UCSC's Summer Edge program is an optional program that offers incoming UCSC students an early start to their college journey. It provides academic preparation, support services, and an opportunity to earn college credits during the summer before their first fall quarter. The program aims to help students transition smoothly into UCSC and get a head start on their academic and social experience. For more information, you can visit the official UCSC Summer Edge page: [UCSC Summer Edge](https://summer.ucsc.edu/summer-edge/index.html)

patterns: What is the cost of attendance at UCSC?
How much does it cost to attend UCSC?
Can you provide information about the expenses associated with attending UCSC?
responses: The cost of attendance at UCSC includes various factors, such as tuition fees, housing, meals, books, supplies, transportation, and personal expenses. The specific cost can vary depending on factors like residency status, enrollment status, and individual choices. It's important to refer to the UCSC Financial Aid Office or the official UCSC website for the most up-to-date information on the cost of attendance.

patterns: What is the difference between the FAFSA and the California Dream Act application?
Should I apply for CADAA or FAFSA?
Should I apply for CADAA or FAFSA?
responses:
Students should only complete one of the applications (not both), according to the citizenship requirements below:
1.You are eligible to complete the FAFSA at www.fafsa.ed.gov if you are either a: 
•U.S Citizen •Permanent Resident •Eligible non-citizen •T Visa holder 

2.You are eligible to complete the CADAA at https://dream.csac.ca.gov if you are: 
•Undocumented •Have a valid or expired DACA •U Visa holders •Have Temporary Protected Status (TPS) •Meet the non-resident exemption requirements under AB 540, SB 2000, SB 68

patterns: SAP
Satisfactory Academic Progress
I have a SAP hold
responses: To maintain Satisfactory Academic Progress (SAP) at UCSC, students are required to meet both the GPA requirement of 2.0 or above and the academic pace requirement. The academic pace requirement refers to the minimum completion rate or pace at which students must progress towards their degree. At UCSC, the minimum academic pace is typically measured by the percentage of completed credits or units compared to attempted credits or units. It is important to review the official SAP policy provided by the UCSC Financial Aid Office for comprehensive details on the academic pace requirement, including the specific completion rate and any other criteria applicable to your academic program.

patterns: Is financial aid available to help with off-campus housing costs?
Can I use financial aid for off-campus housing expenses?
Are there any resources or assistance for off-campus housing costs?
how does off campus housing affect financial aid?
responses: When living off-campus, if your financial aid exceeds the cost of attendance, you may receive a refund of the excess funds. These funds can be used for various education-related expenses, including off-campus housing and personal expenses. It's important to manage these funds responsibly and allocate them towards your educational needs, such as rent, utilities, groceries, transportation, and other necessary living expenses.

patterns: What are the different types of student loans available?
Can you explain the types of loans offered to students?
What are my options for student loans?
what are the loan options at UCSC?
responses: There are various types of student loans available, including federal loans such as Direct Subsidized Loans, Direct Unsubsidized Loans, Direct PLUS Loans, and Federal Perkins Loans. Private loans from financial institutions are also an option, but it's important to carefully compare and consider the terms and conditions. For more detailed information on each loan type, you can visit [studentaid.gov/types](https://studentaid.gov/types/loans).

patterns: How does student loan repayment work?
What are the options for repaying student loans?
Can you explain the process of repaying student loans?
responses: Student loan repayment typically begins after you graduate, leave school, or drop below half-time enrollment. The repayment options may include standard repayment, income-driven repayment plans, or extended repayment plans. It's important to review the details of each plan and choose the one that best suits your financial situation. For more detailed information on loan repayment options, visit [studentaid.gov/repay](https://studentaid.gov/repay).

patterns: What are the current interest rates for student loans?
Can you provide information on the interest rates for federal student loans?
How do I find out the interest rate on my student loans?
responses: The interest rates for federal student loans vary depending on the loan type and disbursement date. It's recommended to visit [studentaid.gov/interest](https://studentaid.gov/interest) for the most up-to-date information on current interest rates. Private student loan interest rates may vary among lenders, so it's important to research and compare offers from different financial institutions.

patterns: What is the difference between federal subsidized and unsubsidized loans?
Can you explain the distinctions between subsidized and unsubsidized student loans?
How do subsidized and unsubsidized loans differ?
responses:
Federal subsidized loans and unsubsidized loans both offer financial assistance for students, but there are important differences to note:

- Subsidized Loans: These loans are need-based, and the government pays the interest while you are in school at least half-time, during grace periods, and during deferment periods. You must demonstrate financial need to qualify for a subsidized loan.

- Unsubsidized Loans: Unlike subsidized loans, unsubsidized loans are not need-based, meaning they are available regardless of financial need. However, you are responsible for paying all interest that accrues on an unsubsidized loan, including while you are in school.

It's important to carefully consider your financial situation and review the terms and conditions of each loan type before making a decision. You can find more detailed information on subsidized and unsubsidized loans at [studentaid.gov/sub-vs-unsub](https://studentaid.gov/understand-aid/types/loans/subsidized-unsubsidized).

patterns: What are some circumstances that UC Santa Cruz considers for financial aid appeals?
Can you provide examples of circumstances for which students can appeal their financial aid?
What are the common situations in which students can request a financial aid appeal?
How can I appeal my financial aid?
Can I file an appeal to qualify for more aid?
responses:
UC Santa Cruz considers various circumstances for financial aid appeals. Some examples include loss of income due to layoff or loss of employment, major repairs after a natural disaster, high medical costs not covered by insurance, increased educational expenses above the standard budgets, extension of financial aid beyond 15 quarters or regaining eligibility due to extenuating circumstances, dependency status re-evaluations due to adverse home situations, and unforeseen circumstances that prevented on-time submission of documents or financial aid applications. However, certain circumstances such as high mortgage costs, credit card/consumer debt, and discretionary expenses incurred in many households are not considered in the evaluation of eligibility for financial aid.
 To learn more about the appeals that we offer, please visit https://financialaid.ucsc.edu/appeals/appeals

patterns: Financial aid for study abroad
Financial aid for global learning programs
Financial aid while abroad
How can I get financial aid for study Abroad?
responses:
If you receive Financial Aid, your financial aid package goes with you abroad or away and is redesigned to meet program costs. Regardless of where you go in the U.S. or the world, on a UC Global Learning program, you could receive the same percentage of financial aid that you receive for attending UC Santa Cruz.

To request a financial aid estimate for a program financial aid package before applying to the program, you can follow these steps:

1. Download and complete the Estimate Request Form.
2. Attach the completed form to an email addressed to the UCSC Financial Aid and Scholarship Office at finaid.specialprograms@ucsc.edu.
3. Allow up to four weeks for the estimate request to be processed.

For financial aid advising related to global learning programs, you can visit the UCSC Financial Aid and Scholarships website for Study Abroad and Away Students. If you have specific questions about financial aid on global learning programs, you can email finaid.specialprograms@ucsc.edu.

patterns: Charges
Direct deposit
Student tax forms
Refunds
Billing
Payments
I have questions regarding my refunds
I have questions regarding my charges
I have questions regarding my bill
I need help with my charges
responses: For inquiries related to charges, direct deposit, student tax forms, refunds, and billing, please contact the UCSC Student Business Services office. They specialize in assisting students with these matters and can provide you with the necessary information and support. You can reach the Student Business Services office through their website or contact them directly via phone or email. They will be able to address your specific concerns and provide the guidance you need.
